did.unittitle: Steven W. Giles glass plate negatives and other photographic material

physdesc.extent: in one lantern slide box, one and a half manuscript boxes, and five negative sleeves.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Steven W. Giles glass plate negatives and other photographic material dates from 1898 to circa 1910 and contains 136 items. The collection is composed of glass plate negatives, film negatives, prints, and a scrapbook by Flatbush resident Steven W. Giles. The images show houses, businesses, and street scenes in the Flatbush and Flatlands neighborhoods of Brooklyn, concentrated on or around Flatbush Avenue and Kings Highway. In addition to notable Dutch homesteads such as the Williamson, Story, Jeremiah Lott, Cornelius Kouwenhoven, John Ditmas, and Remsen houses, the collection also includes images of storefronts, taverns, hotels, and barns. The scrapbook contains clippings and ephemera related to Flatbush and Brooklyn social events and cultural news, such as the openings of parks, libraries, and monuments.
Many images are identified with street names, cross streets, house numbers, or owner names. Contact prints exist for most negatives in the collection, as well as a small number of enlargement prints.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: As the date of death of the photographer is unknown, copyright will remain in effect for 120 years following the date of creation. Based on the date range of this collection, all items will enter the public domain by 2030. For information on securing rights to publish or reproduce, please see the Brooklyn Historical Society Reproduction Rights Policy.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Steven W. Giles was an attorney and amateur photographer based in the Flatbush neighborhood of Brooklyn during the early 20th century.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition for this collection are unknown. The collection was accessioned in 1980.
